subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] BPJ's QS keymap proposal #2 (Revised description)
msgSnippet: ... This is the reason I wanted to appeal to a standard. Unfortunately, since QS-SAMPA proved unpopular we re left to debate our personal preferences. ... I
messageBody:
On Dec 29, 2007 3:47 AM, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> On 28.12.2007 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> > Funnily enough, I find the spellings above with lower-case
> > c for alternative #36 quite readable.
>
> And I find them outright painful, which goes to show that
> we really need discussion and experimentation. I guess
> one can get used to anything, though, and while {ck, kc}
> won't be that frequent in either system {cl} for /Vl/
> will, and it would take some getting used to not to read
> it as /kVl/ or /tSVl/. I might well be influenced by
> having read a lot of Sanskrit, Pali and Tibetan in
> transcription, where _c_ = /tS/.

This is the reason I wanted to appeal to a standard. Unfortunately,
since QS-SAMPA proved unpopular we're left to debate our personal
preferences.

> > The similarity between lower-case u and lower-case c is
> > also nice for this allographic pair.
>
> I didn't think of that. Still uppercase _C_ somehow looks
> more like #36.2 to me.
>
>
> > In addition, I like seeing upper-case C for #15. To me,
> > the upper case nicely signals a tall QS consonant.
>
> True, but there is of course no way such a principle can be
> extended to all assignments. The similarity between
> uppercase _C_ and #15 is definitely there (and the same
> principle seems to speak for #14 = {J}! Let's forget that
> uppercase _C_ looks even more like #13! :-)

I don't think there's any way to do this with a single principle. In
the case of QS-Nu I used multiple principles: first the obvious
consonant assignments, then phonetics, and finally visual similarity.

> > Let's do some more comparisons, as you suggested earlier.
> > I'll write a script to do it.
>
> I'm quite far in writing a perl script already, so perhaps
> we shouldn't invent the wheel twice! It's not that
> complicated, but still.
>
> You already have helped a lot since I can use your
> spreadsheet with the equivalents in the various mappings.
>
> It would help a lot if you transcribed the texts on page 25
> of QM into TO though. That's probably much easier for a
> native speaker! I choose those as example texts because they
> have a canonical QS form readily accessible to everyone.

I've already written a script. See next posting. It doesn't deal with
TO, it only converts from one mapping proposal to the others. I'll
take a look at the text in the QM you refer to.

Ted
